WRITING.TEXT:
I've begun to notice a pattern on Reddit. Donald Trump does something scandalous, it's posted on r/news and a few minutes later an anti Trump meme is posted.
Not complaining though, these memes are hilarious.

It seems like it will only work if the protester needs to live. The question popped into my mind whilst I was watching the movie "Suffragette" in class today. In the later part of the movie one of the characters are incarcerated and she goes on a hunger strike. However, the warden and a few guards pin her down and force feed her and whilst the scene was happening I kept thinking "why not just ignore her?". Now I know that it's about her martyrdom and dying for a cause will only strengthen it and blah blah blah you get the picture. So your comment about inmates was perfect.
You could always puppet the other side.
That makes a lot of sense, thank you for the reply!

WRITING.TITLE: My friend made the perfect humble brag.
WRITING.TEXT:
"I really hate being on the front page with 10k upvotes, I get so many notifications and it's really annoying. My phone won't stop vibrating!"
Credit goes to my friend u/TheNorthRemembers111
PS: His post is on 9gag so there's no use snooping around on his Reddit.

WRITING.TITLE: Does anyone know where to find/watch "The Price of Empire" on the internet?
WRITING.TEXT: It's a brilliantly written World War II documentary and I would love to re watch it. However, I have been unable to find a full episode, only [this](http://www.wildbear.tv/work/world-war-ii-the-price-of-empire/) trailer.

WRITING.TITLE: ELI5:Why does hunger striking actually work?
WRITING.TEXT: If, for example a person hunger strikes as a protest against a government, why not simply ignore hunger strikers and let them starve themselves until they either die or give up?
A lush paradise may not exist within IKEA.
I wouldn't say that France was incompetent as much as it underestimated the speed and power of the Wehrmacht.
I see they did the same to the two China's.
